web|url=http://www.snopes.com/2017/08/14/daily-caller-removes-jason-kesslers-byline-from-site/|title=The Daily Caller Removes 'Unite the Right' Organizer Jason Kessler's Bylines From Web Site|date=August 14, 2017|website=Snopes.com|access-date=August 16, 2017}} but ''The Daily Caller'' executive editor defended Kessler's articles.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalmemo.com/right-wing-media-provided-home-white-supremacist-organized-charlottesville-rally/|title=Right-Wing Media Provided Home For White Supremacist Before He Organized Charlottesville Rally|date=August 15, 2017|publisher=}} The website has also published pieces by [[Peter Brimelow]], founder of the white supremacist website [[VDARE]]. === Heckling of Obama === In 2012, ''Daily Caller'' reporter Neil Munro interrupted Barack Obama during one of the President's press conferences, while Obama was giving remarks. Obama said, "The next time I prefer you let me finish my statements before you ask a question." Cutting off Munro's reply, Obama said, "I didn't ask for an argument."https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2012/06/who-neil-munro-and-why-he-interrupting-president-united-states/326859/ Munro's interruption of remarks by the president was widely considered a startling breach of etiquette. Editor-in-chief Tucker Carlson defended Munro's hectoring, saying "As a general matter, reporters are there to ask [questions]" and that he was "proud" of Munro.https://www.politico.com/blogs/media/2012/06/tucker-carlson-defends-heckling-reporter-126302{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/blogs/politico44/2012/06/obama-interrupted-by-heckling-reporter-126301|title=Obama interrupted by heckling reporter|work=POLITICO|access-date=May 11, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/washington-whispers/2012/06/15/obama-heckled-by-daily-caller-reporter-during-immigration-speech-in-rose-garden--|title=VIDEO: Obama Heckled By Daily Caller Reporter During Immigration Speech In Rose Garden|last=Flock|first=Elizabeth|date=June 15, 2012|website=U.S. News}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/barack-obama-heckled-daily-caller-338367|title=Reporter Heckles President Obama, Asks Why He 'Favors Foreign Workers' (Video)|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=May 11, 2018|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/us-news-blog/2012/jun/15/neil-munro-daily-caller-obama|title=Daily Caller reporter interrupts Obama's Rose Garden statement|last=Braiker|first=Brian|date=June 15, 2012|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=May 11, 2018}} Munro later said in a statent that his intention was to ask questions after the president made his remarks but misjudged when the president was closing. "I timed the question believing the president was closing his remarks, because naturally I have no intention of interrupting the President of the United States. I know he rarely takes questions before walking away from the podium. When I asked the question as he finished his speech, he turned his back on the many reporters, and walked away while I and at least one other reporter asked questions."https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2012/06/who-neil-munro-and-why-he-interrupting-president-united-states/326859/https://www.politico.com/blogs/politico44/2012/06/obama-interrupted-by-heckling-reporter-126301 === Stefan Halper === ''The Daily Caller'' was the first news outlet to report on Stefan Halper, a confidential FBI source, and his interactions with Trump campaign advisors [[Carter Page]] and [[George Papadopoulos]]. Papadopoulos later pleaded guilty to lying to the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] about campaign matters.{{cite web |first=Joseph |last=Tanfani |url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/washington/la-na-pol-essential-washington-updates-former-trump-campaign-aide-george-1509374196-htmlstory.html |title=Former Trump campaign aide George Papadopoulos pleads guilty to lying to the FBI agents in Mueller probe |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=November 12, 2018 |date=October 30, 2017}} Page became the subject of surveillance warrants issued by the [[United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court]] regarding his alleged contacts with Russian intelligence officials.{{cite magazine |last1=Beckwith |first1=Ryan Teague |last2=Abramson |first2=Alana |date=February 1, 2018 |title=Who Is Carter Page? Meet the Donald Trump Advisor at the Center of the GOP Memo |url=http://time.com/5128614/carter-page-gop-memo-fisa-warrant/ |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |location=New York, NY |publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]] |access-date=2018-11-12}} Other news outlets confirmed Halper's identity but did not report his identity because US intelligence officials warned that it would endanger him and his contacts.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/rosenstein-wray-to-meet-with-trump-amid-brewing-controversy-over-fbis-use-of-confidential-informant-in-russia-probe/2018/05/21/b3da543e-5d06-11e8-a4a4-c070ef53f315_story.html|title=White House plans meeting between intelligence officials and GOP lawmakers on FBI source|last=Zapotosky|first=Matt|date=May 21, 2018|work=Washington Post|access-date=May 22, 2018|last2=Kim|first2=Seung Min|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|last3=Leonnig|first3=Carol D.|last4=Barrett|first4=Devlin}}{{Cite news|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/05/the-fbis-trump-campaign-informant-what-you-need-to-know.html|title=The FBI’s Trump Campaign Informant: What You Need to Know|last=Hart|first=Benjamin|work=Daily Intelligencer|access-date=May 22, 2018|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/justice-department/was-there-really-spy-inside-trump-campaign-president-says-n875516|title=Was there really a federal spy inside the Trump campaign?|work=NBC News|access-date=May 22, 2018|language=en-US}} === Allegation of non-profit abuse === According to Callum Borchers of ''the Washington Post'', ''the Daily Caller'' has "a peculiar business structure that enables it to increase revenue while reducing its tax obligation."{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/06/02/charity-doubles-as-a-profit-stream-at-the-daily-caller-news-foundation/|title=Analysis {{!}} Charity doubles as a profit stream at the Daily Caller News Foundation|last=Borchers|first=Callum|date=June 2, 2017|work=Washington Post|access-date=June 18, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} The organization, a for-profit company, does this by relying on its charity arm, ''the Daily Caller'' News Foundation, to create the majority of its news content.{{Cite news|url=https://www.exposedbycmd.org/tucker-carlson|title=Exposed: Tucker Carlson, His "Charity," and the Trump Campaign Cash He Didn't Tell FOX Viewers About - EXPOSEDbyCMD|date=June 1, 2017|work=EXPOSEDbyCMD|access-date=June 18, 2018|language=en-US}} According to Lisa Graves, a deputy assistant attorney general in the Clinton administration, the situation is “a huge rip-off for taxpayers if ''the Daily Caller'' News Foundation is receiving revenue that it doesn't pay taxes on, to produce stories that are used by the for-profit enterprise, which then makes money on the stories through ads.”{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/06/02/charity-doubles-as-a-profit-stream-at-the-daily-caller-news-foundation/|title=Analysis {{!}} Charity doubles as a profit stream at the Daily Caller News Foundation|last=Borchers|first=Callum|date=June 2, 2017|work=Washington Post|access-date=June 19, 2018|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} === Imran Awan === ''The Daily Caller'' kept conspiracy theories surrounding [[Imran Awan]] alive with aggressive coverage.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/congressional-it-staffer-reaches-plea-deal-that-debunks-conspiracy-theories-about-illegal-information-access/2018/07/03/3f22786a-7e30-11e8-b0ef-fffcabeff946_story.html|title=Ex-congressional IT staffer reaches plea deal that debunks conspiracy theories about illegal information access|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=July 3, 2018}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/florida-politics/buzz/2018/07/03/federal-prosecutors-debunk-conspiracy-theory-involving-ex-wasserman-schultz-aide/|title=Federal prosecutors debunk conspiracy theory involving ex-Wasserman Schultz aide|last=Leary|first=Alex|work=Tampa Bay Times|access-date=July 3, 2018|language=en-US}} Imran Awan was an IT worker for [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] in the [[U.S. House of Representatives]]. ''The'' ''Daily Caller'' sought to tie Awan to a wide range of alleged criminal activity, including unauthorized access to government servers.{{Cite news|url=https://gizmodo.com/feds-debunk-it-staffer-conspiracy-theory-pushed-by-the-1827322016|title=Feds Debunk IT Staffer Conspiracy Theory Pushed by The Daily Caller and Trump|last=Cameron|first=Dell|work=Gizmodo|access-date=July 3, 2018|language=en-US}} The reporter behind the aggressive coverage of Awan told Fox News that the affair was "straight out of James Bond." An 18-month investigation by federal prosecutors found no evidence of wrongdoing in Awan's work in the House and no support for the conspiracy theories about Awan. In the announcement of the conclusion of the investigation, investigators rebuked a litany of right-wing conspiracy theories about Awan. === Chinese email hacking === In August 2018, ''The Daily Caller'' ran a story alleging that a Chinese-owned company hacked then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's private email server and successfully obtained nearly all of her emails. The Daily Caller cited “two sources briefed on the matter.” After publishing the story, President Trump tweeted the allegations made in ''Daily Caller'''s reporting. The FBI rebutted the allegations.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/fbi-rebuts-trump-tweet-about-china-hacking-clinton-s-email-n904811|title=FBI rebuts Trump tweet about China hacking Hillary Clinton's email|work=NBC News|access-date=August 29, 2018|language=en-US}} According to ''The Washington Post'', the claims are without evidence.{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-without-citing-evidence-says-china-hacked-hillary-clintons-emails/2018/08/29/cdbd6c60-ab71-11e8-8a0c-70b618c98d3c_story.html|title=Trump, without citing evidence, says China hacked Hillary Clinton’s emails|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=August 29, 2018}} == Awards == *2012 [[Edward R. Murrow Award (Radio Television Digital News Association)|Edward R. Murrow Award]] for "[http://dailycaller.com/2011/10/14/secret-mission-the-horse-soldiers-of-911/ Horse Soldiers of 9-11]" by Alex Quade{{cite web|title=List of 2012 Edward R. Murrow Award winners|url=http://www.rtdna.org/content/2012_national_winners|work=Radio Television Digital News Association}} *2012 American Legion Fourth Estate Award for "[http://dailycaller.com/2011/10/14/secret-mission-the-horse-soldiers-of-911/ The Horse Soldiers of 9-11]" by Alex Quade{{cite web|title=List of American Legion Fourth Estate Award winners|url=http://www.legion.org/presscenter/fourthestate}} *2012 Telly Award for "[http://dailycaller.com/2011/10/14/secret-mission-the-horse-soldiers-of-911/ The Horse Soldiers of 9-11]" by Alex Quade{{cite web|title=List of Telly Award winners|url=http://www.tellyawards.com/winners/list?l=A&pageNum_winners=36&totalRows_winners=3245&event=&category=}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.dailycaller.com ''Daily Caller'' official site] * [http://washingtonindependent.com/73364/carlson-launches-rights-answer-to-huffpost Carlson launches rights' answer to Huff Post] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100114103139/http://dailycaller.com/letter-from-tucker/ Letter from Tucker] * [http://dctrawler.dailycaller.com/ DC Trawler] {{DEFAULTSORT:Daily Caller, The}} [[Category:American political blogs]] [[Category:American news websites]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2010]] [[Category:Conservatism in the United States]] [[Category:Libertarianism in the United States]] [[Category:Tea Party movement]] [[Category:American conservative websites]]

{{Distinguish|The Emperor's New Clothes}} {{Infobox book | name = The Emperor Wears No Clothes | title_orig = | translator = | image = The Emperor Wears No Clothes.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | author = [[Jack Herer]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Social history]] | publisher = Ah Ha Publishing,
Quick American Archives (11th Edition) | release_date = [[1985 in literature|1985]] | media_type = Print ([[Paperback]]) | pages = 330 | isbn = 0-9524560-0-1 | followed_by = }} '''''The Emperor Wears No Clothes''''' is a non-fiction book written by [[Jack Herer]]. Starting in 1973, the story begins when Herer takes the advice of his friend, "Captain" Ed Adair, and begins compiling tidbits of information about the ''[[Cannabis]]'' plant and its numerous uses,{{cite book|author=Herer, Jack|date= 1985|title=The Emperor Wears No Clothes|publisher= Ah Ha Publishing|location= Van Nuys, CA}} including as [[hemp]] and as a [[Cannabis (drug)|drug]]. After a dozen years of collecting and compiling historical data, Herer first published his work as ''The Emperor Wears No Clothes'', in 1985. The twelfth edition was published in November 2010,{{cite book|author=Herer, Jack|date=2010|title=The Emperor Wears No Clothes|edition=12th}} and the book continues to be cited in Cannabis rescheduling and re-legalization efforts.{{cn|date=January 2017}} The book, backed by H.E.M.P. (United States), Hanf Haus (Germany), Sensi Seeds/[[Hash, Marihuana & Hemp Museum]], [[Amsterdam]], (Netherlands), and T.H.C., the Texas Hemp Campaign (United States), offers $100,000 to anyone who can disprove the claims made within. Quoting from the book's back cover: {{quote|If all fossil fuels and their derivatives, as well as trees for paper and construction were banned in order to save the planet, reverse the [[Greenhouse Effect]] and stop [[deforestation]]; then there is only one known annually renewable natural resource that is capable of providing the overall majority of the world's [[paper]] and [[textile]]s; meet all of the world's transportation, industrial and home energy needs, while simultaneously reducing pollution, rebuilding the soil, and cleaning the [[Earth's atmosphere|atmosphere]] all at the same time... and that substance is -- the same one that did it all before -- Cannabis Hemp... [[Marijuana]]!}} The title of the book [[allusion|alludes]] to [[Hans Christian Andersen]]'s classic fairy tale "[[The Emperor's New Clothes]]" (1837). Herer uses Andersen's story as an allegory for the current prohibition of Cannabis. European expert on hemp and author of the doctoral thesis ''Crop physiology of fibre hemp'' (1994), Dr. Hayo M.G. van der Werf criticized the book for containing some inaccuracies, stating, "Although most of the information contained in the book is valid, some of its claims are clearly incorrect."{{cite web|url=http://druglibrary.org/olsen/hemp/iha/iha01213.html |title=Hayo M.G. van der Werf : Hemp facts and hemp fiction |website=Druglibrary.org |date= |accessdate=March 28, 2014}} ==See also== * [[Chemurgy]] * [[c:File:Jack Herer - The Emperor Wears No Clothes.pdf|''The Emperor Wears No Clothes'' at Wikimedia Commons]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Cannabis}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Emperor Wears No Clothes}} [[Category:1985 books]] [[category:1985 in cannabis]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:Cannabis law reform]] [[Category:Cannabis media in the United States]] [[Category:Non-fiction books about cannabis]] [[Category:American books about cannabis]]

revision.text:
{{redirect|Town Parks|parks in towns|urban park}} In the history of land use in Ireland, a '''townpark''' or '''town park''' was a [[smallholding]] near a town and farmed by someone resident in the town.<ref name="CrawfordFoy1998">{{cite book|last1=Crawford|first1=W. H.|last2=Foy|first2=R. H.|title=Townlands in Ulster: Local History Studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oUY6GT1cJC4C&pg=PA97|accessdate=24 November 2014|date=1998|publisher=Ulster Historical Foundation|isbn=9780901905840|page=97 |quote=Elsewhere in Ulster townlands so close to the town were often divided into small fields called townparks because they were let only to the townspeople.}}</ref> Typically, a major landowner provided a contiguous area near the town which was subdivided into multiple townparks, each rented on a short-term lease, for a higher rent than that paid by a full-time resident farmer.
==Townlands== The Boundary Survey of 1825–44, associated with [[Griffith's Valuation]] and the [[Ordnance Survey of Ireland]], set down the names and denominations of subdivisions of land. Griffith often erected a contiguous block of townparks into a single [[townland]] named "Town Parks" or "Town Parks of [name of town]". The 1901 townland index recorded such townlands by the following towns: [[Ballycastle, County Antrim|Ballycastle]], [[Larne]], [[Ballymena]], [[Antrim, County Antrim|Antrim]], [[Ballymoney]], [[Ballyhaise]], [[Cavan]], [[Cloyne]], [[Midleton]], [[Lifford]], [[Ballyshannon]], [[Newtownards]], [[Skerries, County Dublin|Skerries]] (Holmpatrick civil parish), [[Swords, Dublin|Swords]], [[Ballinasloe]], [[Galway]], [[Portumna]], [[Castledermot]], [[Athy]], [[Birr, County Offaly|Birr]], [[Daingean]] (then Philipstown), [[Carrick on Shannon]], [[Longford]], [[Newtown Forbes]], [[Ardee]], [[Dundalk]], [[Navan]], [[Athboy]], [[Kells, County Meath|Kells]], [[Borris-in-Ossory]], [[Mountmellick]], [[Roscrea]], [[Carrick-on-Suir]], [[Cahir]], [[Lismore, County Waterford|Lismore]], [[Delvin]], [[Wexford]], [[Lismore, County Waterford|Lismore]], [[Tallow, County Waterford|Tallow]], [[Tuam]], [[Donaghadee]], and [[Killeshandra]].<ref name="townlands1901">{{cite book |url=http://histpop.org/ohpr/servlet/PageBrowser?path=Browse/Census%20(by%20date)/1901/Ireland&active=yes&mno=453&tocstate=expandnew&display=sections&display=tables&display=pagetitles&pageseq=897 |title=1901 Census of Ireland: General topographical index |year=1904 |series=[[Command paper]]s |volume=Cd.2071 |publisher=HMSO |pages=886–7 |accessdate=24 November 2014}}</ref> There were also "Town Fields" ([[Borrisokane]]), "Town Lands" ([[Clonakilty]]), "Town Lot" ([[Tipperary (town)|Tipperary]]), "Town Lots" ([[Bantry]]), and "Townplots" ([[Kinsale]] and [[Killala]]).<ref name="townlands1901"/> Town Parks was also the townland containing the centre of [[Belfast]]; it is listed in the 1861 index,<ref>{{cite book |title=General Alphabetical Index to the Townlands and Towns, Parishes, and Baronies of Ireland: Based on the Census of Ireland for the Year 1851 |series=Command papers |url=http://histpop.org/ohpr/servlet/PageBrowser?path=Browse/Census%20(by%20date)/1861/Ireland&active=yes&mno=411&tocstate=expandnew&display=sections&display=tables&display=pagetitles&pageseq=886 |year=1861 |page=874}}</ref> but was entirely within the [[county borough]] boundary by 1901.<ref name="townlands1901"/> [[Thurles Townparks]] is the townland, now almost entirely urbanised, around the historic centre of [[Thurles]].<ref>{{cite book |url=http://histpop.org/ohpr/servlet/PageBrowser?path=Browse/Census%20(by%20date)/1901/Ireland&active=yes&mno=448&tocstate=expandnew&display=sections&display=tables&display=pagetitles&pageseq=289 |title=Census of Ireland 1901; Area, houses, and population; Volume II: Munster; No.5: County of Tipperary |page=83 |chapter=VII. Area ... and population, together with the valuation ... in 1901; Thurles Urban District |date=1902 |series=Command papers |volume=Cd.1058-IV |accessdate=24 November 2014}}</ref>
==Land Acts== The [[Irish Land Acts]] of 1870 and 1881, which were designed to enable [[tenant farmer]]s to purchase their holdings from landlords, specifically excluded townparks from their terms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1870/en/act/pub/0046/sec0015.html|title=Landlord and Tenant (Ireland) Act, 1870, Section 15 (1)|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=24 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1881/en/act/pub/0049/sec0058.html|title=Land Law (Ireland) Act, 1881, Section 58 (2)|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=24 November 2014}}</ref> This led to [[case law]] interpreting the Acts' definition of "townpark",<ref>{{cite book |last=Stubbs|first=William Cotter |title=The Irish Law Times Digest of Cases 1867–1893 |url=https://archive.org/stream/irishlawtimesan00unkngoog#page/n328/mode/2up |year=1895 |publisher=John Falconer |location=Dublin |pages=cc268–274; §§214–252 |nopp=Y |chapter=Land Law (Ireland) Act, 1881}}</ref> which had three components: # That they adjoin or are near a city or town; # That they bear an increased value as accommodation land beyond their ordinary letting value for merely farming purposes # That they are occupied by a person living in a city or town or its suburbs
A "town" need not be a [[municipality]] with [[town commissioners]] or other government, and conversely a place within the municipal boundary might yet be too far from the built-up area to be considered a townpark. Population was suggestive but not definitive: [[Portglenone]] with 800 people was held not to be a "town", whereas [[Timoleague]] was, with only 366.
==See also== * [[Allotment (gardening)]]
==Sources== * {{cite book |title=The Irish land law and land purchase acts, 1860 to 1901 : (including the congested districts board acts) : together with the rules and forms issued thereunder |first1=Richard R. |last1=Cherry |first2=John |last2=Wakely |accessdate=24 November 2014 |url=https://archive.org/stream/irishlandlawland00ireliala#page/354/mode/2up |pages=355–360 |date=1903 |publisher=John Falconer |location=Dublin |edition=3rd }} *
===References=== {{reflist}}

{{for|Transshipment in the logistics industry|Transshipment}} {{refimprove|date=July 2013}}
In [[information security]], '''transshipment''' is a technique for protecting software services and applications by ensuring they only receive data that they are known to be able to handle safely. The term is analogous to that in the [[Transshipment|logistics industry]] where cargo is offloaded from one means of transport and on to another at a port of entry. With transshipment, [[information]] is extracted from the [[data]] used to send it and then encoded as data that can be handled safely.
== Method ==
With transshipment,<ref>[http://www.deep-secure.com/wp-content/uploads/Transshipment-–-giving-safe-passage-to-business-information.pdf Transshipment - giving safe passage to business information]</ref> messages are intercepted and the business information they carry is extracted. This information is then encoded in a new message using a data format that the receiving application can safely handle.
== Example ==
For example, an email client may be known to handle messages with a simple structure without failure but not the full generality allowed by the standards. Transshipment can then be used to protect the mail client from attackers who can exploit weaknesses in its ability to handle the general case. The transshipment process extracts the business information in the email messages and creates a new message that conveys the same information but using simple structures. So the mail client is protected without knowing details of any weaknesses in its implementation.
== Implementation ==
The transshipment function must handle any and all data sent to it by potential attackers. To be useful the function must be implemented without it being [[Vulnerability (computing)|vulnerable]] to attack. This can be achieved by using [[Guard (information security)|Guard]] technology that separates the implementation into three parts - a destination proxy that interacts with the message originator and extracts the business information from messages, a verifier and a source proxy that creates a new message to carry the business information and interacts with the message recipient. The verifier's role is to ensure that the source proxy is only presented with the business information using the simple data format it is expecting. As a result, the [[attack surface]] is limited to the verifier's interface and that part of the source proxy's interface which is visible through the verifier.
== Advantages ==
Unlike [[antivirus software]] the use of transshipment defends against unknown attacks, and hence [[zero-day attack]]s, and does not require routine updates to signatures or [[Heuristic]]s.

{{Use Indian English|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}}
The '''Vyapam scam''' was an [[entrance examination]], admission and recruitment [[scam]] that was unearthed in the [[India]]n state of [[Madhya Pradesh]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dangerous Corruption in India|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/13/opinion/dangerous-corruption-in-india.html|work=nytimes}}</ref> It involved scamsters including politicians, senior and junior officials and businessmen systematically employing imposters to write papers, manipulate exam hall seating arrangements and supply forged answer sheets by bribing officials.<ref>{{cite news|title=25 mystery deaths and 2,000 arrests: All about MP's Vyapam scam|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/bhopal/25-mystery-deaths-and-2-000-arrests-all-about-mp-s-vyapam-scam/story-Y3dLEQdkEsVyCwuPQXxaXI.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|publisher=Hindustan Times|date=29 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CBI FILES A CHARGESHEET AGAINST 592 ACCUSED PERSONS IN A CASE RELATING TO ALLEGED IRREGULARITIES IN PMT-2012 EXAMINATION CONDUCTED BY VYAPAM|url=http://cbi.nic.in/pressreleases/pr_2017-11-23-1.php|website=cbi.nic.in|publisher=Central Bureau of Investigation, India|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref>
The scam involved 13 different exams conducted by Vyapam, for selection of medical students and state government employees (including food inspectors, transport constables, police personnel, school teachers, dairy supply officers and forest guards) where the final results were rigged. The exams were taken by around 3.2 million students each year, many of whom were actually paid proxies for other undeserving students.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/dec/17/the-mystery-of-indias-deadly-exam-scam |title= The mystery of India’s deadly exam scam |author=Aman Sethi |newspaper=The Guardian |date=17 December 2015 }}</ref> It also included an "engine-bogie" system wherein seating arrangements were manipulated so that a paid smarter student was seated between two others to allow the latter to copy answers from the former.<ref>{{cite news|title=India reeling from Vyapam scandal|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/world/india-reeling-vyapam-scandal-109402|accessdate=8 November 2017|publisher=BBC Online / The Daily Star|date=8 July 2015}}</ref>
[[Madhya Pradesh Professional Examination Board]] (MPPEB), popularly known by its [[Hindi]] acronym "Vyapam" ('''Vya'''vsayik '''Pa'''riksha '''M'''andal), is a self-financed and autonomous body incorporated by the state government responsible for conducting several entrance tests in the state.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vyapam Corruption Case Mystifies India|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/09/world/asia/vyapam-corruption-case-mystifies-india.html|work=nytimes}}</ref> These entrance exams are held for recruitment in government jobs and admissions in educational institutes of the state. The scam involved a collusion of undeserving candidates, who bribed politicians and MPPEB officials through middlemen, to get high ranks in these entrance tests. The scam also led to between 23 and 40 'unnatural' deaths of involved individuals, though unofficial figures run well into more than a 100 custodial deaths including the erstwhile MP Governor's son and deaths in staged road accidents.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Srivastava|first1=Vaibhav|title=Vyapam Scam: The CBI’s Clean Chit Is Not the Final Word on the Matter|url=https://thewire.in/194948/vyapam-scam-cbis-clean-chit-not-final-word-matter/|accessdate=8 November 2017|publisher=The Wire|date=7 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=India Inquiry Into Scandal Over Testing Set to Expand|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/10/world/india-inquiry-into-scandal-over-testing-set-to-expand.html|work=nytimes}}</ref> Cases of irregularities in these entrance tests had been reported since the mid-1990s, and the first [[First Information Report|FIR]] was filed in 2000. However, until 2009, such cases were not thought to be part of an organized ring. When major complaints surfaced in the pre-medical test (PMT) in 2009, the state government established a committee to investigate the matter. The committee released its report in 2011, and over a hundred people were arrested by the police. However none of the accused have been convicted as most of them either suspiciously died in custody or were released on bail.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dixit|first1=Rakesh|title=Vyapam: How a Munnabhai-style Exam Scam Turned Into a Macabre Thriller|url=https://thewire.in/5249/vyapam-how-a-munnabhai-style-exam-scam-turned-into-a-macabre-thriller/|accessdate=8 November 2017|publisher=The Wire|date=1 July 2015}}</ref>
The sheer scale of the scam came to light in 2013, when the [[Indore]] police arrested 20 people who had come to impersonate candidates for PMT 2009. The interrogation of these people led to the arrest of Jagdish Sagar, the leader of an organized [[racket (crime)|racket]] involved in the scam. The state government established a Special Task Force (STF) on 26 August 2013. Subsequent interrogations and arrests uncovered the involvement of several politicians, bureaucrats, MPPEB officials, racket leaders, middlemen, candidates and their parents in the scam. By June 2015, more than 2000 people had been arrested in connection with the scam. These included the state's ex-education minister Laxmikant Sharma and over a hundred other politicians. In July 2015, the Supreme Court of India issued an order to transfer the case to the country's premier investigating agency, the [[Central Bureau of Investigation]] (CBI). In the same year, the Wikipedia page of Vyapam scam became the 19th most viewed page on Wikipedia globally.<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Vyapam-scam-on-Wikipedias-top-20-list/articleshow/48129815.cms Vyapam scam on Wikipedia's top 20 list], July 19, 2015, The Times of India.</ref>
Many senior personnel including Justice Bhushan who heads the Special Investigative team and Indian doctors including Anand Rai (the whistle blower in this case) are of the opinion that the Vyapam scam was functional since the 1990s when they themselves gave their medical exams.<ref>{{cite news|title=25 mystery deaths and 2,000 arrests: All about MP's Vyapam scam|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/bhopal/25-mystery-deaths-and-2-000-arrests-all-about-mp-s-vyapam-scam/story-Y3dLEQdkEsVyCwuPQXxaXI.html|accessdate=8 November 2017|agency=HT correspondent|publisher=Hindustan Times|date=29 June 2015}}</ref> They also believe that Vyapam is just the tip of the iceberg, and similar "systems" of proxies giving medical exams are operational in other states of India as well.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vyapam: India's deadly medical school exam scandal|url=http://medicaliaorg.ning.com/forum/topics/vyapam-india-s-deadly-medical-school-exam-scandal|website=medicaliaorg.ning.com|publisher=IMS (Medicalia.org - The internet medical scoeity)|accessdate=8 November 2017}}</ref>
== The scam ==
Vyapam was entrusted with the responsibility of conducting large-scale competitive tests for admission to various professional courses and for recruitment to government jobs.<ref name="Role of Board">[http://www.vyapam.nic.in/role_of_the_board.htm Role of The Board], Official Site.</ref>
The Vyapam scam involved collusion among exam candidates, government officials and middlemen: undeserving candidates were offered high marks in the exams, in exchange for [[kickback (bribery)|kickbacks]]. The following tricks were used by those involved in the scam:<ref name="tnm_335"/>
; Impersonation : Brilliant students (including previous years' top candidates) or practicing doctors would be paid to impersonate exam candidates. The photograph on the candidate's admit card was replaced by the impersonator's photograph. After the exam, it was changed back to the original. This was done in collusion with the corrupt board officials.
; Copying : Undeserving candidates bribed the board officials through middlemen to be seated strategically next to a brilliant dummy candidate, who was also paid money. The dummy candidate let them copy from his sheet or exchanged the sheet at the end of the exam.
; Manipulation of records and answer sheets : The undeserving candidates would leave their [[Optical mark recognition|OMR]] answer sheets blank or fill in only the answers they were sure about. The corrupt board officials would manipulate records to give these candidates randomly high percentages. To avoid being caught in case of an audit, they would file an [[Right to Information Act|RTI]] request demanding to view these answer sheets, and fill in the answers according to the marks.
; Leaking the answer key : The corrupt board officials leaked the answer key to the selected candidates.
== Unearthing of the scam ==
Cases of malpractice in Vyapam scam had been reported since 1995, and the first FIR was found in 2000 in [[Chhatarpur district]]. In 2004, seven cases were registered in [[Khandwa district]]. However, such reports of malpractice were seen as isolated cases.<ref name="tnm_31892">{{cite news |url=http://www.thenewsminute.com/article/uncovering-vyapam-does-buck-really-stop-bjp-and-chouhan-31892 |title=Uncovering Vyapam: Does the buck really stop with the BJP and Chouhan? |author=Siddhartha Mishra |date=2015-07-06 |publisher=The News Minute }}</ref>
=== 2009-11: Initial probe by committee ===
A report by the Madhya Pradesh Local Fund Audit office for 2007-08 found several financial and administrative irregularities in MPPEB, including unauthorized disposal of application forms.<ref name="tnm_31892"/> It was suspected that the application forms were being destroyed so that they could not be compared to exam admit cards and other records. In 2009, fresh complaints of irregularities in the pre-medical test (PMT) surfaced.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/mp-govt-accuses-vyapam-scam-whistleblower-of-political-affiliation/|title=MP govt accuses Vyapam scam whistleblower of ‘political affiliation’|date=15 March 2015 |work=The Indian Express}}</ref> Indore-based activist Anand Rai filed a [[Public Interest Litigation]] (PIL) requesting investigation into the scam.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article/tests-of-your-patience/294386 |title=Tests Of Your Patience - Jun 01,2015 |work=Outlook}}</ref> In 2009, Chief Minister [[Shivraj Singh Chouhan]] set up a committee headed by the State Joint Director of Medical Education to probe the allegations.<ref name="charu_42_2015">{{cite news|url=http://www.catchnews.com/india-news/42-dead-why-is-shivraj-chouhan-not-facing-more-heat-in-the-vyapam-scam-1435607494.html|title=42 dead: why is Shivraj Chouhan not facing more heat in the Vyapam scam?|date=2015-06-30|publisher=Catch News}}</ref>
In July 2011, MPPEB monitored 145 suspects during the Pre-Medical Test (PMT). Most of the suspects did not turn up, but 8 were caught for impersonating others. This included Kanpur-based Satyendra Varma, who had accepted {{INR}} 4 lakh to appear in place of Ashish Yadav, in Indore.<ref name="IE_held_2011">{{cite news |url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/8-held-for-impersonation-in-premedical-test-in-mp/822230/ |title= 8 held for impersonation in pre-medical test in MP |author=Milind Ghatwai |date=2011-07-26 |newspaper=Indian Express }}</ref> 15 exam toppers from the previous year appeared for the exam. Suspecting that these people were called in to impersonate others or to help candidates cheat by sitting adjacent to them, MPPEB asked them to explain their reasons for re-taking the exams. MPPEB also started using biometric technology: thumb impressions and photographs of all the persons appearing for the exam were taken to be matched during the post-results counselling.<ref name="IE_guilty_2011">{{cite news |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/news-archive/web/mp-medical-admission-scam-guilty-students-to-face-action/ |title=MP medical admission scam: Guilty students to face action |date= 2011-12-30 |newspaper=Indian Express }}</ref>
The committee set up by Chouhan in 2009 submitted its report to the government in November 2011. It mentioned that 114 candidates had passed PMT using impersonation. The candidates, mostly from rich families, had been impersonated by practicing doctors and talented medical students, some of whom had come from neighbouring states of [[Uttar Pradesh]] and [[Bihar]]. The middlemen had charged each candidate {{INR}} 1-4 million. The findings raised concern that several fake doctors admitted through PMT in earlier years might have graduated as practitioners. The possibility of government officials being involved in the scam was also mentioned.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/100-fake-doctors-MP-hit-by-Munnabhai-scam/articleshow/11285266.cms |title=100 fake doctors? Madhya Pradesh hit by Munnabhai scam |newspaper=The Times of India |date=2011-12-29 |author=Lemuel Lall }}</ref>
In December 2011, the MP Government announced that all the students who had gained admissions by fraudulent means would be asked to quit their courses. This included those who had already spent some years taking the course.<ref name="IE_guilty_2011"/>
In 2012, Indore police arrested four people who had come to impersonate candidates in the PMT exam. The arrested had been promised sums ranging from {{INR}} 25,000 to {{INR}} 50,000 each.<ref name="ToI_double_2013">{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/indore/Impostors-double-rate-to-help-aspiring-medicos/articleshow/20962778.cms|title=Impostors double rate to help aspiring medicos |work=The Times of India}}</ref>
=== 2013 MP-PMT exam ===
The massive scale of the Vyapam scam came to light in 2013. On the night of 6–7 July, the Indore police arrested 20 people from various city hotels. These people, 17 of whom were from [[Uttar Pradesh]], had come to impersonate local candidates in the PMT exam scheduled on 7 July 2013.<ref name="DNA_23000_2013">[http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-pmt-scam-23000-page-chargesheet-produced-against-34-accused-1941377 PMT scam: 24,000 page chargesheet produced against 34 accused], DNA India December 27, 2013.</ref> The impersonators had been promised sums ranging from {{INR}} 50,000 to {{INR}} 100,000.<ref name="ToI_double_2013"/> Based on information collected during the interrogation of these 20 impersonators, Indore police found out that an organized racket headed by Jagdish Sagar was involved in the scam. After the arrests and the revelation, Dr. [[Anand Rai]] submitted a complaint to the local Superintendent of Police (economic offence wing), seeking a detailed investigation. He sought probe into the role of MPPEB's chairman, exam controller, assistant controller and deputy controller.<ref name="ToI_hunt_2013">{{cite web |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/indore/Hunt-on-for-MPPMT-racket-mastermind-in-UP-MP/articleshow/20996767.cms |title=Hunt on for MPPMT racket mastermind in UP, MP |work=The Times of India}}</ref>
On 13 July 2013, Jagdish Sagar was arrested in Mumbai.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/indore/STF-files-charge-sheet-against-28-in-MPPMT-scam/articleshow/23601295.cms |title=STF files charge-sheet against 28 in MPPMT scam |work=The Times of India}}</ref> A list containing names of 317 students was confiscated from him. MPPEB's exam controller Pankaj Trivedi, who was not a suspect in the scam at that time, tried to protect these students. He sent a letter to various government departments and the deans of medical colleges, insisting that these students should be allowed admission once they sign an affidavit. The affidavit would state that they didn't use any unfair means, and that their admissions would be canceled if they were found guilty in the police investigations. On 28 September 2013, Trivedi was also arrested, based on Jagdish Sagar's interrogation.<ref name="ToI_fish_2014">{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bhopal/PMT-scam-STF-cops-ignored-role-of-big-fish/articleshow/29391827.cms|title=PMT scam: STF, cops ignored role of big fish|work=The Times of India}}</ref> On 5 October, the Special Task Force (STF) of the police chargesheeted 28 people, including Jagdish Sagar. In December 2013, the STF produced a 23,000-page supplementary [[chargesheet]] against 34 accused in the Indore district court. Out of these 34 accused chargesheeted, 30 were students and their guardians. Four others included Pankaj Trivedi, Dr. Sanjeev Shilpkar and Dr. Jagdish Sagar's accomplice Gangaram Pipliya.<ref name="DNA_23000_2013"/>
=== Other exams probed ===
In November 2013, the STF found that the scamsters had rigged five recruitment tests: Pre-PG, Food Inspector Selection Test, Milk Federation test, Subedar-Sub Inspector and Platoon Commander Selection Test and Police Constable Recruitment Test - all held during 2012 for government jobs in the state. For Pre-PG Test of 2012, MPPEB's former examination controller Dr Pankaj Trivedi and its system analyst Nitin Mahindra provided model answer keys to candidates through photocopies. For the other four exams, the Vyapam officials manipulated the OMR answer sheets by taking them out of the strong room. Different FIRs against 153 people, including Sudhir Sharma, were filed. Sharma had earlier been interrogated by CBI in mining scam of Madhya Pradesh.<ref name="FPJ_2013_rigged">[http://freepressjournal.in/vyapam-gang-had-rigged-5-more-exams/ Vyapam gang had rigged 5 more exams] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812212459/http://freepressjournal.in/vyapam-gang-had-rigged-5-more-exams/ |date=12 August 2014 }}, The Free Press Journal November 30, 2014.</ref> In March 2014, the government announced that the STF was investigating rigging of nine examinations, and 127 people had been arrested.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freepressjournal.in/127-arrested-after-investigations-into-nine-examinations/|title=127 arrested after investigations into nine examinations|date=4 March 2014|work=Free Press Journal}}</ref>
The previous years' PMT exams were also investigated. The STF found that 286 candidates had cleared PMT-2012 through fraudulent means. On 29 April 2014, 27 students of [[Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College, Indore|MGM Medical College]] in Indore were expelled for having used fraudulent means to clear PMT-2012.<ref>[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/27-medical-college-students-expelled-for-alleged-involvement-in-mppeb-scam-684581.html 27 medical college students expelled for alleged involvement in MPPEB scam], IBN Live April 30, 2014.</ref>
In June 2014, the High Court asked the police why several of the accused in the case had not been arrested yet. Following this, the STF made several arrests. On 15 June, the STF arrested the state's former technical education minister and BJP leader Laxmikant Sharma for his alleged involvement in the contractual teachers recruitment scam. On 18 and 19 June 2014, the police arrested over 100 medical students from different parts of the state, for their involvement in the PMT scam.<ref>[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/vyapam-scam-stf-arrests-over-100-candidates-696150.html Vyapam scam: STF arrests over 100 candidates], IBN Live June 19, 2014.</ref>
In September 2014, the STF revealed that Jagdish Sagar's racket had also rigged the entrance exams for recruitment in [[State Bank of India|SBI]] and other nationalized banks. These entrance exams included the [[Institute of Banking Personnel Selection]]'s exams and the SBI Probationary Officer's exam.<ref name="toisbi">[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bhopal/Even-SBI-exams-rigged-by-proxies-of-scam-riddled-MPPEB/articleshow/43055694.cms Even SBI exams rigged by proxies of scam-riddled MPPEB], The Times of India, September 31, 2014.</ref>
== Investigations == Initial investigations into the irregularities were conducted by the various city units of the state police. During 2009-11, a committee established by the state government and headed by the State Joint Director of Medical Education, probed the irregularities in the PMT exam.<ref name="charu_42_2015"/>
After the role of organized crime rackets and politicians in the scam came to light, the state government formed a Special Task Force (STF) of the police on 26 August 2013, to investigate the scam. Several activists and politicians, including members of the major opposition [[Indian National Congress]] party, demanded a CBI probe in the scam under the supervision of the [[Supreme Court of India]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Congress insists on Supreme Court-monitored CBI probe|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/vyapam-scam-congress-insists-on-supreme-court-monitored-cbi-probe/|accessdate=8 July 2015|work=Indian Express|date=8 July 2015|location=New Delhi}}</ref> Chief Minister of Madhya Pradesh, [[Shivraj Singh Chouhan]] did not entertain the suggestion of a CBI inquiry to the probe initially.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Suparna Singh|title=No Crisis, No Resignation: Chief Minister Chouhan After Calling for CBI Inquiry in Vyapam Scam|url=http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/vyapam-scam-chief-minister-asks-for-cbi-inquiry-says-government-should-be-above-suspicion-778985|accessdate=7 July 2015|work=NDTV|date=7 July 2015|location=Bhopal}}</ref> On November 5, 2014, Madhya Pradesh High Court also rejected the Congress leader [[Digvijaya Singh|Digvijay Singh]]'s petition for CBI probe and instead ordered setting up of a special investigation team (SIT) to act as a watchdog for the court.<ref name="toi5nov">[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/City/Bhopal/PEB-scam-PEB-scam-HC-orders-setting-up-of-SIT-says-no-to-CBI-probe/articleshow/45054876.cms PEB scam: PEB scam: HC orders setting up of SIT, says no to CBI probe], ''The Times of India'', November 6, 2014.</ref> The SIT is a three-member team chaired by Justice Chandresh Bhushan, a retired Judge of the Madhya Pradesh High Court. During 2014-2015, the scam was investigated by the STF under the supervision of SIT.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vyapam scam: HC likely to hear govt’s application for CBI probe today|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/hc-likely-to-hear-govt-s-application-for-cbi-investigation-today/article1-1366951.aspx|accessdate=8 July 2015|work=Hindustan Times|date=8 July 2015|location=Bhopal}}</ref>
On 7 July 2015, after controversy about increasing number of allegedly suspicious deaths, Chouhan informed media that he will write to [[Madhya Pradesh High Court|High Court of Madhya Pradesh]] requesting to order a CBI probe into the scam.<ref>{{cite news|title=Will request HC to order CBI probe, MP CM Chouhan says|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Vyapam-scam-Will-request-HC-to-order-CBI-probe-MP-CM-Chouhan-says/articleshow/47970494.cms|accessdate=8 July 2015|work=The Times of India|date=7 July 2015|location=New Delhi/Bhopal}}</ref> On the same day, the opposition National Congress Party requested for resignation of Chouhan to allow fair probe into the scam.<ref>{{cite news|title=Congress calls for MP bandh demanding CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan's resignation|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/congress-calls-for-mp-bandh-demanding-cm-shivraj-singh-chouhans-resignation/articleshow/47978398.cms|accessdate=7 July 2015|work=The Economic Times|agency=Press Trust of India|date=7 July 2015|location=Bhopal}}</ref> Application was filed before the High Court to transfer the investigation to the [[Central Bureau of Investigation]] (CBI), which however ordered to await the decision of the Supreme Court on similar applications. On 9 July 2015, the [[Attorney General for India]] told Supreme Court that State of Madhya Pradesh had no objection whatsoever for transferring the investigation to the CBI, upon which the Supreme Court ordered to transfer the 'criminal cases related to the scam and also the cases related to deaths allegedly linked with scam to the CBI, country's premier investigating agency.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Supreme Court transfers VYAPAM scam investigation to CBI [Read Order] - 1, Law Street|url = http://onelawstreet.com/2015/07/supreme-court-transfers-vyapam-scam-investigation-to-cbi-read-order/|accessdate = 2015-07-11}}</ref> However who will monitor the investigation process was not announced.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://indianexpress.com/article/india/supreme-court-orders-cbi-probe-into-vyapam-scam/|title = Vyapam scam: Let truth prevail, says Shivraj Singh Chouhan after SC orders CBI probe|date = 2015-07-09|newspaper = The Indian Express}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1 = Krishnadas Rajagopal|title = Supreme Court transfers Vyapam investigation to CBI|url = http://www.thehindu.com/news/vyapam-scam-sc-transfers-probe-to-cbi/article7402984.ece|accessdate = 10 July 2015|work = The Hindu|date = 9 July 2015|location = New Delhi}}</ref>
== Key arrests ==
By June 2015, more than 2000 people had been arrested in connection with the scam.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/bhopal/24-mysterious-deaths-2000-arrests-all-about-mp-s-vyapam-scam/article1-1364038.aspx |title= 25 mystery deaths and 2,000 arrests: All about MP's Vyapam scam |date=2015-06-29 |newspaper=Hindustan Times }}</ref>
=== Politicians and bureaucrats ===
; Laxmikant Sharma, ex-Education Minister (M.P) : [[Bhartiya Janta Party]] (BJP) leader [[Laxmikant Sharma]] was the in-charge of MPPEB in his capacity as the state's Technical Education Minister. He was initially arrested for his involvement in the contractual teachers recruitment scam, based on the information recovered from the Excel sheet maintained by Nitin Mohindra. Later, he was also booked for irregularities in the constables recruitment examinations; according to the STF, he recommended names of at least 15 candidates for recruitment as constables.<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bhopal/Laxmikant-Sharma-booked-in-fresh-case-sent-to-STF-custody-till-Nov-21/articleshow/45200233.cms Laxmikant Sharma booked in fresh case, sent to STF custody till Nov 21], November 19, 2014, The Times of India.</ref> He resigned from BJP in June 2014, after being sent to four days police remand.<ref>[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/vyapam-scam-former-madhya-pradesh-minister-laxmikant-sharma-resigns-from-bjp-695469.html VYAPAM scam: Former Madhya Pradesh minister Laxmikant Sharma resigns from BJP], IBN Live June 16, 2014.</ref> Sharma claimed innocence, placing the blame on his officer OP Shukla, and pointed out that his own daughter had failed PMT twice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/from-rss-backed-priest-to-powerful-minister-to-accused/|title=From RSS-backed priest to powerful minister to accused|date=19 June 2014|work=The Indian Express}}</ref>
; O. P. Shukla : He was posted as Officer on Special Duty (OSD) with then Technical Education Minister Laxmikant Sharma. Soon after the investigations gained momentum, he went underground and surrendered two months after the investigation team released a lookout notice for him. He allegedly took 8.5 million (85 lakhs) Rupees from the candidates for clearing the medical entrance test.<ref name="ibn5">[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/stf-arrests-mppeb-scam-accused-op-shukla-666842.html MPPEB scam accused OP Shukla], IBN Live February 7, 2014.</ref>
; Sudhir Sharma : A mining businessman, Sudhir Sharma was once an Officer on Special Duty (OSD) of the education minister Laxmikant Sharma. He was involved in police constable recruitment examination scam of 2012. After absconding initially, he surrendered to the STF in December 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/cities/ahmedabad/exminister-mining-baron-surrender/|title=Ex-minister,mining baron surrender|date=24 December 2013|work=The Indian Express}}</ref> The STF questioned him twice, but did not arrest him at the time. After STF found prosecutable evidence against him, he again went missing. The STF announced a cash reward of {{INR}} 5000 for information on him.<ref>[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/mppeb-scam-stf-declares-rs-5000-reward-for-info-on-sudhir-sharma-695114.html MPPEB scam: STF declares Rs 5,000 reward for info on Sudhir Sharma], IBN Live June 15, 2014.</ref> He surrendered before the court in 2014, and was arrested by the STF.<ref>[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/key-mppeb-accused-sudhir-sharma-surrenders-before-court-704072.html Key MPPEB accused Sudhir Sharma surrenders before court], IBN Live July 25, 2014.</ref> : During 2010-2013, Sharma had provided payoffs to many politicians and bureaucrats, including former Madhya Pradesh BJP chief Prabhat Jha and his sons, Congress MLA Veer Singh Bhuria, several ABVP leaders, RSS functionary Suresh Soni, and many civil servants. Laxmikant Sharma was the biggest beneficiary of his kickbacks. He also received large sums of money from educational institutes regularly.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Vyapam-scam-Congress-BJP-netas-received-kickbacks-from-accused/articleshow/48011760.cms |title=Vyapam scam: Congress, BJP netas received kickbacks from accused |date=2015-07-10 |newspaper=The Times of India }}</ref>
; R. K. Shivhare, Suspended IPS Officer : He is an accused for his alleged involvement in the recruitment of sub-inspector and platoon commander examination of 2012 conducted by Vyapam. He is also an accused in getting his daughter and son-in-law admitted in the medical college by fraudulent means. When the probe agency registered a case against him, he was suspended but evaded arrest. He was declared absconder and a reward or Rs. 3000 was put against him. He later surrendered on April 21, 2014.<ref>[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/suspended-ips-officer-accused-in-mppeb-scam-surrenders-682798.html Suspended IPS officer accused in MPPEB scam surrenders], IBN Live April 22, 2014.</ref>
; Ravikant Dwivedi, Suspended Joint Commissioner (Revenue) : He was arrested for getting his son admitted into one of the premiere medical colleges through unfair means. Later, the state anti-corruption wing raided his house and found cash, jewellery, property worth Rs. 600-700 million.<ref>[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/vyapam-scam-bureaucrat-found-in-possession-of-assets-worth-rs-70-crore-665393.html Vyapam scam: Bureaucrat found in possession of assets worth rs 70 crore], IBN Live Jan 30, 2014.</ref>
=== Racket leaders ===
Several organized [[racket (crime)|rackets]] were involved in the Vyapam scam. These included the gangs led by Dr. Jagdish Sagar, Dr. Sanjeev Shilpakar and Sanjay Gupta, who were described as "[[boss (crime)|kingpins]]" of the PMT scam. For PMT 2013, Dr. Sagar had given 317, Shilpakar 92 and Sanjay Gupta 48 names. Mahendra had recorded the details of these candidates in his computer and destroyed the list. While allotting roll numbers to these candidates, the slots immediately before or after them were left blank. These roll numbers were then allotted to fake candidates. The roll numbers were set at their homes and brought to office in a pen drive. After reaching the office, Mahendra uploaded the roll numbers to the computers. He then used to telephone the middlemen and provide a confirmation.
; Dr. Jagdish Sagar : Indore-based Jagdish Sagar helped around 140 students get selected to the medical courses illegally, during 2009-12 alone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/news-archive/web/lavish-spender-who-struggled-for-mbbs-helped-hundreds-cheat-their-way-in/|title=Lavish spender who struggled for MBBS, helped hundreds cheat their way in |date=23 July 2013|work=The Indian Express}}</ref> He arranged impersonators, largely sourced from Uttar Pradesh. He ran the alleged racket since the late 1990s, and had amassed a huge amount of wealth, including several real estate properties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/premed-test-racket-kingpin-held-in-mp/1143255/0|title=Pre-med test racket kingpin held in MP|work=indianexpress.com}}</ref> He was arrested in 2003 on similar charges, but the police did not keep a watch on him after his release.<ref name="FPJ_lapses_2013">[http://freepressjournal.in/lapses-allowed-pmt-scam-to-thrive-admits-government/ Lapses allowed PMT scam to thrive, admits government], The Free Press Journal July 31, 2013.</ref>
; Dr Sanjeev Shilpakar : Bhopal-based Shilpakar was a junior of Jagdish Sagar in medical college, and started his own racket inspired by him. For PMT 2013, Shilpakar had enlisted 92 candidates, out of which 45 candidates had already paid him {{INR}} 30 million. In turn, Shilpakar had bribed MPPEB officials including Nitin Mahindra, impersonators and brokers who brought candidates to him. He absconded after the arrest of Jagdish Sagar, but was later arrested by the STF.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freepressjournal.in/shilpakar-earned-rs-3-cr-from-45-pmt-candidates/|title=Shilpakar earned Rs 3 cr from 45 PMT candidates|date=31 October 2013|work=Free Press Journal}}</ref>
; Sudhir Rai, Santosh Gupta, Tarang Sharma : This gang was much bigger than (and a competitor to) Sagar's racket, and charged upwards of {{INR}} 2.5 million per candidate. The gang also facilitated admissions to medical colleges in Karnataka and Maharashtra. The Rai-Gupta racket was more organized than Sagar's racket and had branches in Ujjain, Shahdol, Sagar and Ratlam. Rai arranged candidates; Gupta arranged impersonators, most of whom came from Bihar. The gang is believed to have helped over 500 candidates gain admission to medical colleges illegally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/indore/Police-raid-Rais-office-arrested-trio-sent-to-police-remand-till-Aug-5/articleshow/21496502.cms|title=Police raid Rai's office, arrested trio sent to police remand till Aug 5|work=The Times of India}}</ref>
=== MPPEB employees ===
; Pankaj Trivedi, MPPEB Examination Controller : He was arrested in September 2013 and is currently in a judicial custody. The state anti-corruption police has recovered around 25 million rupees and numerous properties from his possession that are unknown to his sources of income. Evidence of his partnership in Indore based medical college was also found.<ref>[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/assets-worth-rs-2-5-crore-found-from-pmt-scam-accuseds-houses-665184.html Assets worth Rs 2.5 crore found from PMT scam accused's houses], IBN Live January 30, 2014.</ref> Even after the Jagdish Sagar's racket was exposed, Trivedi managed to get an order that allowed Sagar's 317 candidates to get admission to medical courses on submission of an affidavit.<ref name="ToI_fish_2014"/>
; CK Mishra, Officer, Vyapam : CK Mishra has admitted that he was working for Dr. Sagar, Santosh Gupta and Sanjiv Shilpkar since 2009. In 2009, Dr. Sagar had given him application forms of 20 candidates, who were to be allotted roll numbers in such a way that in the exam, their seats were one behind the other. Rs 50,000 per roll number was paid to him. Thus, he received Rs 1 million. In 2010, Dr. Sagar gave forms of 40 students. This time Rs 2 million was paid. In 2012, Dr. Sagar took contract of 60 students, Shilpkar gave roll numbers of 20 boys. They paid Rs 3 million and Rs 1 million respectively.<ref name="dna2">[http://dnasyndication.com/showarticlerss.aspx?nid=B02F3/1RAwpweB57arHR161WXbfNbymOZCS/kVtSp0s= Police seize hard disc, one more arrested], DNA India July 20, 2013.</ref>
; Nitin Mohindra / Nitin Mahendra (Principal System Analyst) and Ajay Sen (Senior System Analyst) : Vyapam programmer Yashwant Parnekar and clerk Yuvraj Hingve said in their statements that the computers of Mahindra and Sen were not linked with the main server of Vyapam. These two officers could access the data stored in 25 other computers at Vyapam but the data in their computers could not be accessed by anyone. Taking advantage of this, they allotted roll numbers and examination centers as per their wish.<ref>[http://www.ibnlive.com/news/india/mppeb-scam-directorate-of-enforcement-quizzes-former-system-analyst-in-indore-706261.html MPPEB scam: Directorate of Enforcement quizzes former system analyst in Indore], IBN Live August 5, 2014.</ref>
=== Others ===
; [[Piyush Trivedi]] [[Piyush Trivedi]] is the brother of the tainted and the main accused of the Vyapam scam, '''Pankaj Trivedi'''. == Allegations of threats to whistleblowers and activists ==
; [[Anand Rai]] : Indore-based Dr. Anand Rai filed a PIL which led to an investigation in the scam. He has reported receiving regular threat calls and has also alleged that contract killers were hired to kill him. In 2013, he approached the court requesting security cover. He was told to pay {{INR}} 50,000 per month for police protection, although his monthly salary was only {{INR}} 38,000. In 2015, he was provided with a security guard.<ref name="tnm_335">{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewsminute.com/news_sections/335 |title=I have been asked to shut my mouth, but work will go on- An interview with the whistleblower who exposed Madhya Pradesh Vyapam scam |work=The News Minute |date=2015-06-25 |author=Monalisa Das }}</ref> Rai was accused of being a Congress agent by a BJP spokesperson, but he refuted the accusation pointing out that he had been a member of BJP, and was active in [[Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh]] activities from 2005 to 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://khabar.ndtv.com/news/blogs/why-rss-is-quiet-on-protecting-whistleblower-anand-rai-778943 |title=RSS ने सिखाया पाठ, RSS ने ही छोड़ दिया साथ, जानिए आनंद राय की कहानी - रवीश कुमार |date=2015-07-07 |publisher=NDTV |language=Hindi }}</ref> He has also filed a petition in Supreme Court of India to hand over the investigation of [[DMAT scam]], a private medical college admission scam.<ref name="TI10Jun15">[http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/nation/madhya-pradesh-dmat-exam-cancelled/104907.html Madhya Pradesh DMAT exam cancelled], June 10, 2015, Tribune India.</ref> : In July 2015, Dr. Rai was transferred from Indore to Dhar district. He alleged that it was done to harass him as he lodged a complaint with CBI against former Union minister and BJP leader Vikram Verma. In the complaint it was alleged that Vikram Verma used his influence to get his daughter transferred from [[Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh|Ghaziabad]] to Gandhi Medical College in Bhopal.<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Vyapam-scam-Doctor-who-complained-against-BJP-leader-transferred/articleshow/48144375.cms Vyapam scam: Doctor who complained against BJP leader transferred], July 20, 2015, The Times of India.</ref> : On September 2, 2015, Dr. Rai submitted an affidavit in Madhya Pradesh High Court alleging that Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan met him and proposed to cancel the transfer orders if he stops campaigning against him over Vyapam and DMAT scam. The principal secretary confirmed the meeting but said it was arranged at the request of Dr. Rai as he wanted to share some scam related information.<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Madhya-Pradesh-CM-promised-to-cancel-my-transfer-in-lieu-of-stopping-Vyapam-campaign-Whistleblower/articleshow/48773551.cms Madhya Pradesh CM promised to cancel my transfer in lieu of stopping Vyapam campaign: Whistleblower], September 2, 2015, The Times of India.</ref>
; Ashish Chaturvedi : Gwalior-based social activist Ashish Chaturvedi lodged a complaint against 8 people, one of whom was Gulab Singh Kirar's son Shakti Singh; Kirar is a relative of the Chief Minister. Chaturvedi had also petitioned CBI to probe admissions of 5,000 doctors in MBBS and PG courses of 2003-2013 in all state colleges. He suffered three attacks on his life, including an abduction bid. He has alleged that the police refused to provide him adequate protection after he complained of threats to his life. The police reportedly asked him to pay {{INR}} 50,000 for protection or remain confined in his home.<ref name="ToI_Gwalior_2014">[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bhopal/Gwalior-man-who-blew-lid-on-MPPEB-scam-faces-life-threat/articleshow/39150690.cms Gwalior man who blew lid on MPPEB scam faces life threat], The Times of India July 28, 2014.</ref>
; [[Prashant Pandey (activist)|Prashant Pandey]] : Indore-based Prashant Pandey had been hired as an IT consultant by the Special Task Force (STF) investigating the scam. He was arrested in 2014 for allegedly blackmailing the Vyapam accused using the [[call detail record]]s (CDRs) collected by the investigating team.<ref name="FPJ_blackmail_2014"/><ref name="DNA_trainee_2015">{{cite news |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-vyapam-mysterious-death-of-trainee-woman-cop-is-the-latest-2102312 |title=Vyapam: Mysterious death of trainee woman cop is the latest |newspaper=DNA |date=7 July 2015 |author=Iftikhar Gilani }}</ref> He approached the [[Indian National Congress]] leader [[Digvijaya Singh]], claiming to be a whistleblower who was being falsely implicated for trying to expose the involvement of senior BJP leaders (including Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan) in the scam.<ref name="DNA_trainee_2015"/><ref name="Outlook_Uttam_2016">{{cite news |url=https://www.outlookindia.com/magazine/story/4000-mp-cops-are-using-tapping-sw/297389 |title="4,000 MP Cops Are Using Tapping S/W" |author=Uttam Sengupta |publisher=Outlook |date=4 July 2016 }}</ref> Subsequently, he has reported receiving death threats.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1150706/jsp/opinion/story_29724.jsp |title=Intimations of evil - The Vyapam deaths |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=6 July 2015 |author=Mukul Kesavan }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/all-you-need-to-know-about-the-vyapam-scam/article7402744.ece |title=All you need to know about the Vyapam scam |author=Pradipti Jayaram and Apuurva Sridharan |newspaper=The Hindu |date=9 July 2015 }}</ref> He has also alleged that some unidentified people tried to kill his family by ramming a truck into their car, but the police investigation concluded that his car had collided with a dead cow on the street.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/indore/Whistleblowers-car-hit-cow-carcass-no-murder-bid-Cops/articleshow/47209550.cms |title=Whistleblower’s car hit cow carcass, no murder bid: Cops |date=9 May 2015 |newspaper=The Times of India }}</ref><ref name="FPJ_turtle_2015">{{cite news |url=http://www.freepressjournal.in/indore/car-turned-turtle-as-it-hit-a-dead-cow-not-by-truck/582037 |title=Car turned turtle as it hit a dead cow, not by truck }}</ref> In July 2015, the police briefly detained his wife accusing her of having illegal [[hawala]] cash; Pandey alleged that this was done to intimidate and harass him.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.freepressjournal.in/indore/i-t-dept-to-probe/633548 |title=I-T dept to probe |date=28 July 2015 |newspaper=The Free Press Journal }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/whistleblowers-wife-detained-with-hawala-money-in-indore/ |title=Whistleblower’s wife detained with ‘hawala money’ in Indore |newspaper=Indian Express |date=26 July 2015 }}</ref>
== Allegations against the Governor == The STF also found evidence against the state Governor [[Ram Naresh Yadav]]. On February 24, 2015, Yadav was charged for criminal conspiracy in rigging the MPPEB forest guard recruitment examination.<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Vyapam-scam-FIR-filed-against-MP-governor/articleshow/46358084.cms Vyapam scam: FIR filed against MP governor], The Times of India, Feb 24, 2015.</ref> His son Shailesh was an accused in the contractual teachers' recruitment and later found dead in mysterious circumstances in March, 2015. His former officer-on-special-duty Dhanraj Yadav was arrested by STF in 2013 in connection with the scam. The Governor petitioned the High Court arguing that no criminal proceedings could be initiated against him, as the [[Constitution of India]] grants him immunity while he is in office. The High Court agreed and stayed his arrest, but ordered the investigations against him to proceed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/madhya-pradesh/vyapam-scam-hc-stays-arrest-of-mp-governor-ram-naresh-yadav_1580232.html|title=Vyapam scam: HC stays arrest of MP Governor Ram Naresh Yadav|work=Zee News}}</ref> The SIT chief declared that the investigators will act against Yadav after his retirement in September 2016.<ref>[http://www.firstpost.com/politics/god-save-governor-despite-vyapam-scam-taint-ram-yadav-enjoy-modi-govts-favour-2328888.html God save the governor: Despite Vyapam scam taint why does Ram Yadav enjoy Modi govt's favour?], Firstpost.com, July 6, 2015</ref> Three advocates petitioned the [[Supreme Court of India|Supreme Court]] to order removal of Yadav as Governor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianage.com/india/supreme-court-moved-removal-madhya-pradesh-governor-057|title=Supreme Court moved for removal of Madhya Pradesh governor|work=The Asian Age}}</ref> A bench comprising [[Chief Justice of India]] [[H. L. Dattu]] and Justices [[Arun Kumar Mishra]] and [[Amitava Roy]] has agreed to hear the petition on July 9.<ref>[http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/vyapam-scam-sc-agrees-to-hear-plea-seeking-removal-of-mp-governor/ Vyapam scam: SC agrees to hear plea seeking removal of MP Governor Ram Naresh Yadav], The Indian Express, July 6, 2015</ref> Now, The CBI will investigate the Vyapam scam and more than 30 deaths allegedly linked to the job recruitment scandal, the Supreme Court ruled on 9 July 2015.
== Allegations against the Chief Minister ==
In 2014, Prashant Pandey (aka "Mr. X"), an IT consultant hired by the STF, was arrested for trying to use the team's information to blackmail the Vyapam accused.<ref name="FPJ_blackmail_2014">{{cite news |url=http://www.freepressjournal.in/bhopal/pandey-was-blackmailing-vyapam-accused-had-links-with-stf/418838 |title=Pandey was blackmailing Vyapam accused, had links with STF |date=2014-08-08 |author=Satyadev Katare |newspaper=The Free Press Journal }}</ref> Pandey then approached the [[Indian National Congress]] leader [[Digvijaya Singh]], and claimed that he was a whistleblower who was being harassed for exposing the role of Chief Minister [[Shivraj Singh Chouhan]] in the scam. He alleged that the investigating agencies had tampered with the contents of the [[Microsoft Excel|Excel]] sheet recovered from hard disk of the scam accused Nitin Mohindra's computer. Mohindra maintained a record of the candidates' names, their roll numbers and the names of those who had recommended them. Hundreds of people were arrested based on the information in this sheet. Pandey claimed that the investigators had modified the original version of the sheet by removing the names of senior BJP leaders, including Chouhan, from the sheet.<ref name="ToI_lab_2015">{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bhopal/Gujarat-lab-report-gives-clean-chit-to-STF/articleshow/47037072.cms |title=Gujarat lab report gives clean chit to STF |date=2015-04-25 |newspaper=The Times of India }}</ref>
Digvijaya Singh then submitted a 15-page affidavit before the SIT, alleging that the investigators were shielding the Chief Minister. SIT took cognisance of Singh's complaint, and sent both versions of the Excel sheet for forensic analysis. The forensic laboratory reported that the Excel sheet available with STF was genuine, while Pandey's version was forged.<ref name="ToI_lab_2015"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/vyapam-scam-digvijaya-submitted-forged-evidence-sit-tells-court/ |title=Vyapam scam: Digvijaya submitted forged evidence, SIT tells court |date=2015-04-25 |author=Milind Ghatwai }}</ref> Accordingly, Singh's submission was rejected as a forgery by Justice Khanwilkar in the MP High Court.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/excel-evidence-presented-by-digivjaya-singh-was-forged-says-court-757953?pfrom=home-lateststories |title=Excel 'Evidence' Presented by Digvijaya Singh Was Forged, Says Court |date=2015-04-24 |publisher=NDTV |author=Siddharth Ranjan Das |editors=Abhishek Chakraborty }}</ref>
Pandey stood by his version, and stated that it had been authenticated by Truth Labs, a private forensic lab.<ref name="ToI_lab_2015"/> He approached the [[Delhi High Court]] for protection as a whistleblower, claiming persecution by the MP Police. He claimed that he first sent the documents to the BJP minister [[Kailash Vijayvargiya]] and the Prime Minister's Office; he approached Congress leaders only when he did not receive any response.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/i-had-to-go-public-when-real-documents-didnt-come-out-vyapam-scam-whistleblower-to-ndtv-749030 |title=Delhi Police withdraw Vyapam whistleblower’s security |date=2015-03-03 |author=Sunetra Choudhury |publisher=NDTV }}</ref> Pandey also stated that he was getting threat calls from influential people. The Delhi court therefore ordered police protection for him in February 2015. However, it was withdrawn in mid May 2015.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/delhi-police-withdraw-vyapam-whistleblowers-security/|title=Delhi Police withdraw Vyapam whistleblower’s security |date=2017-05-17 |publisher=The Indian Express |author=Press Trust Of India}}</ref>
Chouhan hit back at his critics, saying that his government should be credited for the exposing the scam. He stated that only 228 out of 350,000 appointments made during his tenure had been affected by the recruitment scam, and unlike previous governments, he had conducted a thorough probe. Replying to Congress' allegations that his wife had got jobs for 17 of her relatives from Gondia, he pointed out that not a single candidate from Gondia had got the job in the question.<ref name="HT_Uttam_2014">{{cite news |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/i-should-get-credit-not-persecution-for-exposing-scam-shivraj-singh-chouhan/article1-1242097.aspx |title= I should get credit for exposing Vyapam scam: Shivraj Singh Chouhan |author=Kumar Uttam |newspaper=Hindustan Times |date=2014-07-19 }}</ref>
== Deaths == A number of people connected to the scam and its investigation, died during the course of investigation. The opposition parties and activists alleged that several of these deaths happened under suspicious circumstances. In 2015, the Special Task Force (STF) submitted a list to High Court, naming 23 people who are believed to have died "unnatural death". According to the STF, most of these deaths took place before it took over the investigation in July 2013. Some media reports claimed that 40+ people associated with the scam had died under mysterious circumstances.<ref name="IE_Narendra_2015">{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/vyapam-scam-accused-narendra-singh-tomar-dies/|title=24th Vyapam death: 29-yr-old Narendra Singh Tomar has ‘heart attack’, kin protest|date=2015-06-29|newspaper=Indian Express|author=Milind Ghatwai}}</ref>
The State Government dismissed the allegations, arguing that Vyapam conducts very large-scale examinations and thousands of people are admitted or recruited through these exams every year. Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan insisted that death of every person linked with Vyapam exams should not be linked to the Vyapam scam.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-vyapam-scam-now-a-trainee-sub-inspector-commits-suicide-2102091 |title= Every death should not be linked to Vyapam, says MP CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan on Anamika Kushwaha's suicide |date=2015-07-06 |newspaper=DNA }}</ref> The state's Home Minister [[Babulal Gaur]] claimed that the deaths were "natural".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/vyapam-scam-accused-deaths-natural-babulal-gaur/1/447767.html |title=Deaths of Vyapam scam accused were natural: MP Home Minister Babulal Gaur |publisher=NDTV |date=2015-06-29 }}</ref>
According to whistleblower Anand Rai, 10 of these deaths are suspicious, while the rest might be coincidences. The deaths considered as suspicious by him include the deaths of Akshay Singh, Namarata Damor, Narendra Tomar, D K Sakkale, Arun Sharma, Rajendra Arya and four middlemen who died in road accidents.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/vyapam-scam-10-deaths-were-suspicious-rest-may-be-a-coincidence-says-anand-rai/articleshow/47967026.cms |title=Vyapam scam: 10 deaths were suspicious, rest may be a coincidence, says Anand Rai |date=2015-07-07 |newspaper=Economic Times }}</ref>
According to the High-Court Special Investigation Team (SIT), 32 people in 25-30 age-group identified as 'racketeers' during the investigation, died in suspicious circumstances since the investigation started in 2012. The SIT officials raised concerns that the arrested people were naming those who were already dead, in order to mislead the probe.<ref name="ToI_Nobody_2015">{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bhopal/Nobody-knows-how-40-PEB-accused-died/articleshow/47454826.cms |title=Nobody knows how 40 PEB accused died |date=2015-05-28 |author=P Naveen |newspaper=The Times of India }}</ref>
The following is a list of "unnatural deaths" mentioned in the STF and SIT records, plus other deaths alleged to be "suspicious" by the opposition parties and the media.

Other accused declared dead in SIT's report include the following:<ref name="ToI_Nobody_2015" /><ref name="HT_mishaps_2015">{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/ht-exclusive-vyapam-scam-has-10-dead-in-mishaps-4-suicides/article1-1364275.aspx|title=HT Exclusive: In Vyapam scam, 10 dead in mishaps and 4 suicides|date=2015-06-30|newspaper=Hindustan Times}}</ref>

== Reactions on social media == The mysterious deaths of people linked to Vyapam scam triggered [[Black comedy|dark humour]] on various [[social media]] platforms across India. People compared it to the fictional television series ''[[Dexter (TV series)|Dexter]]'' and termed it as India's version of ''[[Game of Thrones]]''. The untimely and sudden death of a journalist soon after interviewing the family members of another dead accused was considered inauspicious. An online perception was created that any sort of link to the scam could bring trouble or even mysterious death.<ref name="htjul1015">[http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/mystery-vyapam-deaths-spark-a-wave-of-dark-humour-on-social-media/article1-1367620.aspx Mystery Vyapam deaths spark a wave of dark humour on social media], July 10, 2015, Hindustan Times</ref>
Various hashtags such as #KhooniVyapam (Bloody Vyapam), #killervyapamscam, #vyapam, #VyapamGenocide, and #shivrajisteefado (Shivraj, resign) were used by people to post their reactions.<ref name="htjul1015" />
== Judgement == On February 13, 2017, the Supreme Court of India delivered an 83-page judgement and cancelled the degrees of 634 doctors. The court said:
{{block quote | The actions of the appellants are founded on unacceptable behaviour and in complete breach of rule of law. Their actions constitute acts of deceit...National character, in our considered view, cannot be sacrificed for benefits - individual or societal...If we desire to build a nation on the touchstone of ethics and character, and if our determined goal is to build a nation where only rule of law prevails, then we cannot accept the claim of the appellants (students) for suggested societal gains (by allowing them to keep the degrees on the condition of doing social service free of cost for some years)..We have no difficulty in concluding in favour of rule of law... Fraud cannot be allowed to trounce, on the stratagem of public good.<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/vyapam-scam-supreme-court-cancels-degrees-of-634-doctors/articleshow/57136149.cms Vyapam scam: Supreme Court cancels degrees of 634 doctors], Feb 14, 2017, The Times of India.</ref>}}
